segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Good. Okay. Today we are going to talk a little bit about the work we are doing at a global
level, fighting a proposed UN cybercrime treaty. But before I start to discuss what's on the
text of the treaty, I want to give a little of how we end up with this treaty and these
global negotiations. So there is already a global cybercrime treaty. It's not global, it's
international. It's the Budapest Convention and has been the main existing treaty for
international cooperation, like one country helping another investigate a crime in
cross-border spying powers. It was finalized in 2001 and recently has been extended next year.
Next. Next. Yeah. And it has, we have been criticizing that treaty for many, many, many
problems. And Budapest has become the, the fact of standard for many countries. So
Budapest has like 64 countries, next, and many of the countries have already adopted many of
the computer crimes that are in Budapest. However, um, and many countries have also used it
as a model law, even if they have not ratified. However, some countries like Russia has
objected to the Budapest Convention because sitting concerns that it infringed on our
sovereignty by allowing other nations to investigate a crime in their own country. That's
one of the main reasons why Russia proposed a new cybercrime convention at the UN in
2017. At that moment, we thought this is not going to go forward. But in 2019, the UN
General Assembly adopted a resolution that create this ad hoc committee. Next. Um, okay, I
do it. This ad hoc committee, uh, tasked with the job of elaborating this proposed UN
cybercrime convention. And this proposal was put forward by Russia, Belarus, Cambodia,
China, Iran, Myanmar, Nicaragua, Syria, Venezuela. Many countries opposed it, including the
United States and the EU, and with concerns that this treaty could infringe on people's
freedom. Let's fast forward to, to 2002, and the UN just started the actual negotiations of
this draft treaty, with member states submitting some proposed steps. Russia having
illegally invade Ukraine in that moment was considered less than fully credible on
respecting sovereignty, which was his claim why the treaty, you know, didn't work in the
first place. But nevertheless, Russia got the ball rolling, and many of the proposals made it
to the first negotiating text. But geopolitics is always messy. And in 2000, as the
negotiation opposed it, many of the countries who were originally opposed to the treaty
decided to engage in the negotiations, and pursuing their own agendas. While forming alliance
in essential global negotiations is like necessary to get consensus and move, uh, move, uh,
proposals forward, it could also be complicated, because it could end up compromising the
standards of human rights protections. And regrettably, instead of progressing towards a
pro-human rights treaty, the current version of the draft, and it's called Zero Draft, which
was released two weeks ago, it's um, this, the first negotiated draft that is on the table, is
moving away from it. The Zero Draft has five chapters. One on criminalization, that we talk
about computer access, and all the color, color's crimes, and also a chapter on domestic
surveillance, cross-border surveillance, technical assistance, and proactive measures. The draft
convention has two articles on human rights. One article five, that will apply to the whole
treaty, uh, general one, and one on safeguards, that will apply only to the domestic powers.
Um, this article 24 is very weak, not even strong enough, but even those articles, uh,
some countries want to delete them from the treaty. Um, interesting enough, when it comes to
international cooperation, the previous draft made clear that human rights should apply also to
the cross-border spying powers, the international cooperation chapter. However, that was
removed. Um, during the discussions leading to this Zero Draft, countries such as India, Russia,
China, Iran, Syria, Egypt, and Tonga, have even proposed to delete reference to the
international human rights obligation, this article five, which is concerning, and even
objective on the language of the limitations of domestic spying powers, making it even weaker
than Budapest. So, why we care about treaties? Treaties are binding, uh, for the countries who
decide to sign it, who are obliged to comply with it, with them. Some treaty provisions
compel states to adopt certain laws to implement such obligations. They use child, uh, the
state shall implement, shall adopt domestic legislation. And some others will say a state may
adopt domestic legislation. Sometimes a state can make reservations and say, oh, I can
exclude from that provision only if a treaty allow it. It's not always the case. And this is
problematic because, uh, when you come and have a law discussed in Congress, most of the core
features of the treaty has already been negotiated. So there are little things you can do at
the domestic level. Of course, you will try to find flexibility, these flexibilities that
could, you could use to get better safeguards in place, or better protections for human
rights, or whatever you want to include in the treaty. But this is a sour, uh, it's, it's, it's
not always useful to have flexibility because sometimes it could be problematic for human
rights. For instance, the treaty doesn't compel states to adopt mass surveillance powers, but
also doesn't foreclose it. Meaning that if a state, like the USA state, will use the
particularity standard or the more standards to limit, um, surveillance powers, others could
decide not to do that. So that, that's why it's problematic to have too much flexibility. But
sometimes it could be good because you can have people trying to advocate for better
protections, especially when it comes to criminalization. Um, so right now, uh, we are, the
assembly in 2001, that's a little, uh, the general assembly finally provide a draft
convention to the treaty. There's six sections to negotiate. It was from March 22 until 2023.
And it's supposed that the treaty will be finalized in January 2024, but we don't know yet.
We will see. The coming negotiations is going to be in two weeks, August 21st, and we hope the
treaty keeps negotiating. I, I think there are too many red lines in the treaty to be able to
get a consensus, but we don't know. And so far, according to the timeline, it's going to be
finalized in January. So, why, uh, what we are doing here. So, let's discuss the chapter of
criminalization. A matter of time, I won't be able to deal with everything. We are not going to.
So, but, um, the treaty is very broad, and so we don't have the time with everything. But, um, one
of the main concerns is the crimes that are in the criminalization section. Usually these are
the core cybercrimes, and we call core cybercrimes in the U.N., they call core cybercrimes to
those who are computer access without authorization, illegal interference, misuse of
devices, interference of data, interference of systems, uh, et cetera, illegal
interception, et cetera. But, uh, before there were more than 30 crimes, so in that sense we won.
Many countries like Russia and China, but also many other, not authoritarian, but in the
middle were proposing fake news crimes and many other crimes that can criminalize a speech. Um, so
that's out of the treaty. However, there always is a loophole, and this loophole is called
Article 17, in which it compels states to adopt, to make a cybercrime, to make a
cybercrime, any other applicable cybercrime treaty that exists. Imagine, there is a treaty of
terrorism of Lyme, smuggling, narcotics, now they all have to turn it into cybercrime. And
that's all. Making something of Lyme and turning it into cybercrime is a problem because
many of the provisions of Lyme, they don't have problems like criminal liability by
intermediaries. They have not been fought, uh, under those, how these crimes will be
committed under which conditions. And so making this automatic translation could create a
lot of problems. So we are asking to delete this loophole. Um, but, um, what is more
important is that, uh, the crime have these articles of computer access without
authorization that you already know maybe from the CFAA. However, what is new here is
first, the older convention, uh, the Budapest Convention was ratified by 60 countries. So 60
countries have those crimes in their books. I don't know, many others may have adopted, but
it's not the 194 countries around the world. Meaning, by adopting this treaty, and if we
get consensus, all countries around the world will have these crimes. And it's not only that
it's a problem. It's that it also has an article on jurisdiction. When a state can claim
jurisdiction on the investigation of crime. And the real issue of this treaty is international
cooperation. Once all countries have in their books this crime, they can help each other
investigate a crime, and they can easily claim jurisdiction for the investigation and
extradition of a crime and extradition of the person accused. So, yeah, so Article 22 have,
you can claim jurisdiction if the offense happen which is territory. A state can claim
jurisdiction if the offense involve a national event, um, if you are not in the territory,
whether they are victims or perpetrators. Also, if the offense is planned outside, but
committed in their territory, or if the state is, uh, against the state itself. Um, let's make
a case to understand this. And a simple one first. If a security researcher from country A
without authorization access a database in country B, and country B has a jurisdiction
because the offenses happen within its territory. But if the researcher is a national, also
this country B, or target a national of country B, country B can also claim jurisdiction. And,
um, and even while operating from the United States, let's say, country A, country B can
still claim jurisdiction in, in those cases. And if there is multiple countries
investigating the crime, they have to coordinate. But they don't say how. And this is very
problematic at a global level when you have different countries with different standards of
human rights protections. So let's see a little more complex scenario. A security researcher
from country A, let's say a democratic nations, identifies a vulnerability and without
authorization, without rights, access a database in country B. Let's say country B is an
authoritarian regime. The database, which is unknown to the researcher at that time,
contains sensitive information about dissidents from country C, which also is an
authoritarian regime. So we have country A democratic, country B and C authoritarian. And
information about dissidents from country C. The researcher's intentions are purely
academic. But implications are political and sensitive. So what would happen here,
could country B would likely want to claim jurisdiction over the matter since the
unauthorized access occurred in their territory. Given the nature of the laws in that country,
they might paint the researcher as a spy or a foreign agent and demand extradition. Country
C would also be deeply concerned as their national data was compromised. Even though the
researcher has no malicious intent, the sensitive information possibly, the sensitive
information nature means that country C would likely also claim jurisdiction over the
matter. Possibly painting it as an act against the state, which is also another clause in the
article 22. If the researcher travels to country C for any reason, or if country C can somehow
apprehend him, country C would want to establish its own jurisdiction over the researcher.
Over the researcher, especially if country A, imagine the United States, don't want to
punish that person. Since both country B and C, that both authoritarian regimes have a
stakes issue, there will be a diplomatic tussle. And when there is diplomatic issues, it gets very
complicated and murky. The two authoritarian regimes might coordinate or even blame country A
for supposed espionage or interference. Country A, being a democratic country, would find
itself in a very difficult position. And depending on the international relationship, treaties,
geopolitical strategies of that country, country A might be forced to either protect or distance
themselves or even hand over the researcher to the country. So we are calling for article 22
also to be deleted. Because once you claim jurisdiction, other laws could apply to them. And
this is very mathematical also for the surveillance powers, because some countries' laws,
for instance, when claim jurisdiction may have laws that are very draconian and have very
little standards, it can create obligations on providers to localize data among other issues.
That will make it easier for them to access data. So I think I will pass to Bill about, but
just to make very clear, while these articles are already in the GFAA, we think that most
importantly, we need to have limitations here. And we need to make sure that computer access
without authorization means breaching a security measure that is done with dishonest
intentions, causing harm. And there should be a public interest protection for the public
interest. This article is not only applicable to security researchers. Many of the work of
journalists sometimes involve finding information that is very obscure on the Internet. But
it is public available. And if it's just using a simple tool to get access to information
that is public available, that could make them a crime. And then we have all these other
repercussions. The treaty itself is a treaty about international cooperation, meaning now
country, whatever country, can help the other country to investigate that crime. We are
fighting for dual criminality to make sure that the crime that is being investigated is a
crime in both countries, but that's not mandatory. Right now it's just optional. And even
two countries who are authoritarian regimes may allow each other to help each other
investigate a content related crime, a crime that is inherently illegal in international law.
Laissez Majesté, for instance, insulting the king. So they will use the whole surveillance
powers to investigate a crime that is that. For us, that's providing a legal, I think that
the treaty, what it's doing is providing a legal basis for authoritarian regimes to rank among, to
legitimize the illegal prices of international cooperation on crimes that are not worth it, or
should not be subject of criminal investigation. So I pass.
Thanks very much, Katica. So, as Katica mentioned, Articles 5, which kind of applies to the
entire treaty, and Articles 24, which applies to the new investigative powers with regards to
human rights, the human rights limits on the new powers that are delegated to states that are
signatories to the treaty. What we want to push are stringent limitations to the new powers on
surveillance. We would love to see the UN Cybercrime Treaty in general be just discarded, but
at the very least there should be stringent safeguards on human rights abuses that are
possible. One thing that we want is to set time limits on investigative powers and
surveillance. So if there is an investigation going on, then set strict time limits for when that
cooperation will happen. Effective remedy, which is when someone is targeted for
investigation, and they are targeted wrongly, then they should have the ability to then in the
future seek remedy, seek some kind of justice for what happened to them. We want to require
prior judicial review when a surveillance power is brought to the table. There should be, in the
country which is employing the surveillance technology, a judicial oversight that happens
prior to it actually being implemented. So an infactual basis for any crime that is being
alleged has to be a paper trail for why you think this is a crime that is being committed and
that there could be vetting on both sides and not just arbitrary statement that this is
happening by say an authoritarian regime forcing investigation on someone who is in the
jurisdiction of a democratic society. Finally, we want the investigative committee to
tell the public how often these new powers were used. Somewhat like a transparency report for
the amount that these new powers were used so that we know if there is massive abuse
happening, say mass surveillance. So we want these strong protections to be incorporated
within article 24 on the new investigative powers. So we want a new bolstered article
5 which applies generally to the convention and article 24 which applies to these new
surveillance powers. One of the things that's problematic throughout the treaty, the
zero draft, is the term competent authorities which is not defined. So in these
conventions you'll have a long text and the terms and definitions will be in the first few
articles. Article 2 in this case defines a whole slew of terms but not competent
authorities which appears throughout the treaty. And competent authorities could be
interpreted as prosecutors or law enforcement by countries which adopt this. So we want
that to be better defined and not to apply to say overzealous prosecutorial authorities.
And what should be most relevant for the DEF CON community is perhaps article 28. So
article 28 empowers the search and seizure of stored data allowing competent authorities to
compel those with device knowledge to disclose information about how to access data on these
devices. Say security researchers who know about a vulnerability in a device or network and
they are given, investigative authorities are given new powers to compel them to take part in
an investigative. This is open, the wording is open to interpretation but it can be
interpreted as forced disclosure of security vulnerabilities to government authorities. So
this is something that we at EFF feel very strongly about and also has to do with another
piece of pending international legislation which is the EU Cyber Resilience Act. And that's
another piece of legislation which may compel companies to report vulnerabilities to EU
regulatory authorities when there is a vulnerability that they know of. Basically it's
trying to rein in the irresponsible companies from not doing their due diligence with regards
to end devices and patching vulnerabilities. But the good actors in the space of cyber
security are reasonably terrified of this because vulnerabilities are very justifiably so
regarded as well kept secrets in the industry and they don't want to alert regulatory
authorities to continue the spread of information about a vulnerability before, for
instance, it's able to be fixed and pushed. So these are kind of, it's a new push by
governments to get information on vulnerabilities both in the UN Cybercrime Treaty and the
EU Cyber Resilience Act. So what is next? Next is the 6th session of the Cybercrime
Convention which will happen and will be attending in August and September and that is when an
intensive round of negotiations will happen around the text. We're trying to get these
protections built into the text of the convention and that will be incorporated into a final
draft if we can hopefully have some input on the process. Although they're not obliged to
listen to us in any way, shape or form. But then in January, February of 2024 is when it will
go into effect and there can be new signatories. But that deadline, January, February 2024
may be pushed back if there's not agreement in member states. So we're trying, we're trying
to stand up for users' rights and the rights of security researchers not to be criminalized
in the international forum and we hope that you will all follow this closely.
Thank you.
